channel.title: Bayes on Wesenheit
channel.description: Recent content in Bayes on Wesenheit

item.title: IrisML - Neural Posterior Estimation for Spectral Energy Distribution fitting
item.description:
• Authors: Mateusz Kapusta
  • Journal: ICML 2025: Machine Learning for Astrophysics workshop Link

Fast and reliable real-time inference for astronomical data? Now possible with Simulation-Based Inference.

item.title: Approximate Bayesian Computation with Wrocław trams
item.description:
Introduction

Recently, I presented some results from the field of Simulation-Based Inference at the Statistical Journal Club at the Astronomical Observatory. While modern neural networks allow the creation of some incredible models that allow for the Likelihood Free Inference (LFI), there are also some more old-school examples from the field of statistics. Those were usually labeled as the Approximate Bayesian Computation (ABC) methods. Here, I would like to write something about the classical implementation and apply it to one of my favorite problems known as the German tanks problem (although here there will be trams).

item.title: Search for dormant black holes in the OGLE data
item.description:
• Authors: Mateusz Kapusta, Przemek Mróz
  • Journal: Acta Astronomica Link

Are there any black holes that are dormant (no X-ray signature) and reside in ellipsoidal binaries? Spoiler: probably not.

item.title: GMVAE clustering applied to RNA sequencing
item.description: Traditional clustering methods typically rely on the raw, observed features of data. However, we can often achieve better results by using Variational Autoencoders (VAEs) to create an embedded representation of the data first.
